Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Selenium hyperaccumulation in a rapid radiation of legumes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Milkvetch (Neo-Astragalus) species from the legume plant family known as selenium hyperaccumulators are restricted to soils rich in the element selenium, where they accumulate the element in their tissues at levels that are toxic to other organisms. This research will determine the number of origins of selenium hyperaccumulation in milkvetch species by reconstructing the group's evolutionary history using DNA sequence data. The project will also sequence genes thought to be involved in selenium hyperaccumulation to determine if they have been subject to natural selection. This research will provide one graduate student and undergraduates with training in molecular, chemical, and bioinformatics techniques and will also supply molecular resources for population genetic studies of poorly known North American Astragalus species.

Twenty-five Neo-Astragalus species from two traditional taxonomic groups have been identified as selenium hyperaccumulators; however, it is not known if these groups are monophyletic. The researchers will sample these selenium hyperaccumulators and other species from across the clade and reconstruct a phylogeny using a target-enrichment approach for sequencing low-copy nuclear loci in order to infer the number of times selenium hyperaccumulation has evolved. Analytical chemistry methods will be used to survey selenium accumulation in relevant species, and phylogenetic ancestral state reconstruction will be used to characterize the number of origins of selenium hyperaccumulation from the resulting phylogeny. This approach can quantify the relative contribution of ecologically driven speciation and allopatric speciation in light of the number of origins of the cryptic trait, their phylogenetic position, and geographic ranges of the different species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from this grant has allowed us to clarify the evolutionary relationships in a large group of plants called Neo-Astragalus, a group of about 450-500 North and South American species in the legume genus Astragalus (commonly called milkvetches or locoweeds). About two dozen Neo-Astragalus species have developed the ability to hyperaccumulate selenium, in other words they concentrate selenium from the soil they grow in to the point they are highly toxic to organisms that might eat them, including livestock. Neo-Astragalus is a very young group, relatively speaking, and this has in the past made understanding how these species are related to each other using DNA sequences from a small number of their genes quite difficult. We developed new molecular resources and sequenced DNA from hundreds of genes in many Neo-Astragalus species to help us determine whether these selenium-hyperaccumulating species all share a single common ancestor or whether this trait has developed multiple times independently.

Using preliminary sequence data and analyses, we carefully selected over 600 genes likely to help us estimate how Neo-Astragalus species are related to each other or that are expected to be involved in how these plants process selenium to better understand how these plants can accumulate so much without being poisoned themselves. After collecting over 100 milkvetch species across 11 western states over the whole project, we sequenced the genes we selected in a set of 96 samples that included all reported selenium-hyperaccumulating species and sampled broadly across the entire Neo-Astragalus group to produce a set of sequence data with far more genes and more species in this group than had been before. With this data set we have begun to resolve relationships among Neo-Astragalus species that have long remained mysterious. The relationships we recovered from a subset of the genes analyzed thus far show the selenium hyperaccumulators in five different unrelated groups. If remaining genes give similar results as those already analyzed, it could indicate there have been multiple independent origins of selenium hyperaccumulation in Neo-Astragalus. The DNA sequence data we have generated will also allow us to determine whether evolution has occurred on the same genes in these potentially multiple origins to allow these plants to accumulate high levels of selenium.

This grant helped improve the doctoral dissertation of Co-PI Charboneau. It also aided in his development as a scientist in providing opportunities for extensive training and experience in collecting and identifying plant specimens, performing molecular biology and analytical chemistry lab techniques, processing and analyzing large amounts of DNA sequence data, inferring evolutionary relationships among species using such data, and presenting results at two national meetings. The Co-PI also enhanced his professional development by collaborating with scientists at three other public universities and the USDA Forest Service and through working with federal and tribal land management agencies to obtain plant collection permits. The Co-PI mentored a recent college graduate in learning molecular biology lab techniques to help produce some of our data as well. We also presented engaged visitors of all ages in outreach activities on learning about how evolutionary relationships among different species are depicted in the Tree of Life at a large, annual public event for three years.

Many of the impacts of this research are yet to come as we continue analyses of the large data set we produced with support from this grant. Not only will this work shed light on how new species can rapidly form by developing important but difficult to detect differences in the way they use resources, but the products of our research will also have applications outside of evolutionary biology. Twenty Astragalus species are on the federal endangered or threatened species list, and the DNA sequence data we have produced will be an excellent resource for conservation work on those and the many other imperiled milkvetches monitored by federal land management agencies as well as state and tribal natural heritage programs. A better understanding of Neo-Astragalus selenium hyperaccumulators may also help range managers reduce losses from selenium poisoning in livestock. Our work on the genetic basis for selenium hyperaccumulation could also help develop fast-growing plants that could be used to clean up contaminated industrial sites with high levels of selenium. Selenium is not always toxic; humans and all other animals require small amounts of selenium in their diets to survive. Many people live in areas of the world with very low levels of soil selenium and do not get enough selenium in their diets. Fast-growing plants that can accumulate lots of selenium could also be harvested and then used as an input into soil in these parts of the world to help people and livestock get adequate amounts of selenium.
